utterances: Not yet.
Not yet.
You better buy one of those cars.
College student Jessica Marcado took Schwarzenegger's advice.
She camped out overnight to get a bargain on a car.
For the car I got and the price I got it for, I think it was totally worth it.
What was the car?
A Chevy Cavalier.
It's a 2002, 55,000 miles, and I got it for 2,800 bucks.
The state expects to net around $1 million from the garage sale.
That's pennies in the piggy bank by California's standards.
Lawmakers recently closed a $20 billion-plus hole in the state budget.
For NPR News, I'm Marianne Russ in Sacramento.
The fickleness of Mother Nature doesn't just affect oysters and Wall Street.
Oh, that's a fact.
Mother Nature affects the crabs a whole lot more than it does Wall Street (unintelligible).
Where are you, Captain Don Pierce?
Right here off Cape Charles.
I should say Don Pierce is a crab fisherman.
He's one of the first out on the Chesapeake Bay.
The season began on April 1st.
How's the haul been so far?
Well, it's still too cold.
Crabs move by the water temperature, and the water temperature is still too cool because of the cold spring.
Well, crab season is being watched especially closely this year because last year, as I understand it, there was a worry about the number of crabs out there off the coast of Maryland and Virginia.
And so, they ended crab season early.
And you, sir, lost a lot of money.
It was a disaster.
I mean, you just can't survive with a bad economy.
Actually, we laid people off this fall.
With the new regulations on the crabs, we couldn't do much.
And the guy that buys crabs is thinking about his gas tank, thinking about his mortgage, thinking about trying to keep his family fed.
Crabs are $200, $225 a bushel.
This was a poor man's delicacy, the crabs, a lot of the seafood.
Now, it's a rich man's delight.
I mean, a poor man can't afford to buy crabs.
So with all these challenges facing the crabbers, what are you and the other crab boats doing differently this year?
How have you changed in order to make this an actual profitable venture out there?
As a catcher, you're going to have to come up with a different way to sell your product, maybe cut some of the middle people out.
So you say cut the middle people out.
What does that mean, just putting the crabs on the back of your truck and
That's exactly what it's going to mean.
Really?
You'll be out on the highway selling crabs?
Yeah.
And, you know, you'll get - probably, you'll get a better crab, you'll get a cheaper crab, a more affordable crab, let's put it that way.
The only ones that are still left out here (unintelligible) are the survivors.
The rest of them have already went up inland and got jobs or done something else.
How many traps did you pull up today?
We fished about 200, not right around 200 crabs.
So we've got just about - at market price, it's just about $1.50 to the (unintelligible), $300.
And that's just about what it cost us to come out here today (unintelligible).
It's better than a zero, but it ain't much better than a zero.
Because it costs you that amount of money just to take the boat out?
And it takes about $150 worth of fuel and $100 worth of (unintelligible).
Got two people on here getting $100 a (unintelligible).
That means (unintelligible) about $125 in the (unintelligible).
So those people who have lost their jobs and are thinking, you know, I'm just going to give it all up and get a boat and go out and take what nature gives us for free and sell it.
Mr.
{IERCE: Oh, if you know somebody who wants to buy a rig that wants to go crabbing, you tell them come see me.

For the refugees who are in Jordan or Syria, do they also have to show not just that they have a fear of persecution in Iraq, but that it's not safe for them to stay where they are, that they need to come to the United States?
Absolutely.
The criteria are based on whether these particular refugees will be able to integrate and adapt in the country of first asylum.
So you have several criteria of vulnerability.
One of them is women-headed household.
It would be extremely difficult for women-headed household family with no man to really be able to earn a living in Syria and Jordan.
Unaccompanied minors are in a similar situation.
It's going to be very difficult for them to integrate.
What about translators or other Iraqis who've worked for the United States in Iraq?
Are they had any sort of fast track?
They are supposed to be, but unfortunately, it is only in Jordan that the U.S.
has a program for fast-tracking.
Basically, the U.S.
has put in place an over - an overseas processing entity to process these cases so that, so as to skip the UNHCR side of the processing.
But unfortunately, Jordan has closed its borders, so basically people who haven't made it Jordan are - have no way to apply.
And for those who are inside Iraq, there is no solution at the moment.
The pace of admitting Iraqi refugees seems to be accelerating somewhat.
And Homeland Security says it expects that twenty-four hundred Iraqis per quarter will be admitted.
Do you think that's realistic?
Well, we're certainly hoping it's going to happen.
However, past experience has showed that the processing has been extremely slow.
And now, we have seen more than 500 people arriving in the month of August, which is more than in the rest of the year combined.
So this is, of course, very encouraging.
I think it is extremely ambitious to expect twenty-four hundred per quarter.
Certainly, I believe they can do it, but we really need to see the resources and we need to see the commitment to do that.
Kristele Younes is an advocate with Refugees International.
Ms. Younes, thanks for coming in.
Thank you for having me.
As it turns out, there's a phrase for what happened to Fran O'Connor, a phrase that's being used more and more as climate change makes the East Coast of the U.S.
increasingly unstable.
It's called managed retreat.
And this week in New York, there was a first-of-its-kind conference on this subject that tackled this question, when does it make sense to retreat?
NPR's Nathan Rott is at the conference at Columbia University, and he joins us now on the line.
Hi there.
Hey, Lulu.
So explain that phrase to us - managed retreat.
What does it mean?
So it's a technical term, a political term.
And it is essentially like a formal acknowledgement that there are places in the U.S.

and around the world - not just the East Coast, I should say - that are going to be, if they aren't already, at such huge levels of risk from climate change that it just won't make sense for those places to remain.
And that can be, you know, communities at risk of increased wildfire heat.

But primarily, what we're talking about at this conference - it's focused on the impacts on coastal zones - cities by the sea, oceanside towns that are going to be inundated or see more flooding as sea levels rise.
We've been reporting on coastal communities dealing with climate change all year, and we've seen the ways that places are trying to defend themselves from rising seas - seawalls or artificial reefs.
Are you saying those won't work?

So this is one of the big challenges that I've been hearing about at this conference - that it is hard to speak in these sort of broad universal truths, you know, that this will work or this won't because there's still so much uncertainty about what the impacts might be from climate change in some places or how severe they'll be.
One of the presenters here - her name is A.R.
Siders.
She's been studying climate adaptation for a long time.
She's currently at Harvard University.
And she says that there's really no one-size-fits-all solution.
What is the right answer in Louisiana is going to be different from the right answer in Alaska or Boston or New York or Miami or California.
It's going to change.
So instead of saying, this is the thing you need to do, I find it a lot more useful to say, these are the questions you should consider while making the choice that's right for your context.
But many people won't want to leave their homes or the places that they grew up, right?
No.
I mean, nor does a city manager, who gets a huge percent of their budget from property taxes, want to see any of that go away.
And that's why managed retreat, to this point, has largely been looked at as sort of an option of last resort.
But we should say there are communities, you know, namely native communities on Alaska's coast, who have wanted to be relocated for years, but the funding just hasn't been there.
